subsections.title: Ionosphere, Sunspots, Sporadic E
subsections.label: subsec:ionosphere
prompts: Explain the role of the ionosphere in HF and VHF radio wave propagation, including how it refracts or bends signals.
Describe the impact of sunspots on HF propagation, particularly during periods of high and low sunspot activity.
Discuss the phenomenon of Sporadic E and its effects on the 10, 6, and 2 meter bands.
Explain how multi-path propagation affects data transmissions, including the potential for increased error rates.
Describe the characteristics of VHF signals received via auroral backscatter, including signal distortion and strength variability.
Explain the concept of knife-edge diffraction and how it allows radio signals to travel beyond obstructions.
Discuss the best bands and conditions for communicating via meteor scatter.
Explain the optimal times for long-distance 10 meter band propagation via the F region during high sunspot activity.
Describe why the radio horizon for VHF and UHF signals is more distant than the visual horizon, including the role of atmospheric refraction.
